As expected in Chinese restaurants, there are typos on the English menu: you can buy sandwishes.

Previously, they would only open until 2pm and there were lines in front every time I drove by. Now they open later and I don't have to wait as long. You can get wontons or, my favorite, dumpling. The dumplings are a combination of the wonton meat AND an individual shrimp, which makes it huge! When you bite into the dumpling, you get a thinly sliced mushroom that adds a nice fresh crisp to the dumpling. I always get noodles and drink all of the soup, even though my tongue is dry afterward. 

On the weekdays between 11am-3pm, if you order two or more items from a certain part of the menu, you get an item for free! There's a picture of that menu on the photos portion of this restaurant.

Also, the head chef in the back is very nice. She's the only one that speaks perfect English and, once in a while, comes out. When she does, she gives the best service, and with a smile!
author: Vanson N.

description:
Nothing beats a bowl of silky, smooth porridge. Call me an old man, but I absolutely love eating this stuff! :O

They added Pork Blood Porridge to their menu. Well, it's on the wall (in chinese), so we decided to try it. We also ordered a beef stew lo mein. The blood was really soft, but lacked taste. The cilantro and ginger over powered the delicacy of the blood; a bit of a disappointment. The beef stew lo mein was so rich. Few bites in and I felt full. There wasn't much meat either; most of the piece were tendon. 

Overall, today's experiences wasn't the greatest, but the porridge is what gets me! I've eaten here a many times and I'm never too disappointed was I leave. I guess stick to my regular order (Sampan porridge and Chinese donut rice roll) would of been better than being adventurous today.
author: Derrick H.

description:
This hole in the wall may be missed because of this tree in front of it. It is next to the okazu-ya sushi restaurant and the black building that is the firefly lounge and bar.

I go to this place because of the ginormous fricking dumplings(won-tons). They are pretty huge sized and I usually find more than 1 shrimp in each one! The beef brisket is always pretty good as well but the noodles are just mediocre. The other food I always get here is the "JAH-LERNG" which is chinese doughnut with rice roll wrapping. It comes with a sweet hoisin-like sauce and some peanut sauce which makes it much more appetizing.

Probably the only drawback:
It is somewhat expensive for won-ton noodles
Sometimes, the service is especially slow too.
author: Wilson T.

description:
I love this place! Walking inside, it definitely has a hole-in-the-wall cozy feeling. The restaurant primarily consist of noodle soup dishes which is perfect for cold weather. We had the cha siu & won ton noodles which were great. I would suggest ordering egg noodles over their ramen just because I think the texture provides a better balance. Their cha siu is  very flavorful and fatty. The won tons are huge and stuffed with yummy filling. AND, if you go during lunch time and order two dishes, you can get your choice from three items (choy sum vegetables, cheung fun, or...something else...i don't remember) for free. 

If you're health conscience, I don't recommend coming here as the broth is pretty oily. But then again, I don't normally suggest Chinese food if you want to eat healthy. If you don't mind the fatty goodness, I would definitely check this place out!

Cash only! Bring the bills.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
A gloomy and rainy day led us to get won ton soup for lunch.  We walked in at lunch time and were seated right away.  I think they get busy because they have a wait list hanging on the wall.  

Don't expect ambiance cause there ain't any here.  4 huge shrimp won tons floated in my broth and they gave me my BBQ pork on a side plate, (thanks!) so it didn't get soggy.  My bf got the BBQ pork ramen dish.  We couldn't figure out if they used fried ramen or the fresh kind.  If it's fresh then thumbs up for them.  

The staff was friendly and understood my sorry-ass mandarin.  I'd come back here since it's close by and if I craved won tons again.
author: Rosalind S.

description:
We hadn't yet eaten in the Sunset District, and a friend from China said it was her favorite restaurant in the city; a little hole-in-the-wall with amazing wonton soup that wasn't oily, so it would seem nice and light, though a decent portion.

I have to admit, the shrimp wonton and dumpling soup I ordered was quite nice. The wontons and dumplings were both huge, and tasty, and served crazy-hot. The vibe of the place is definitely a little dumpy. I like hole-in-the-wall actually, but there were definitely some easy, cheap/free things that they could have done to improve the aesthetic... such as cleaning up a bit better... that would have gone a long way.

Bottom line: I'd go back. But I wouldn't drive back. If I were in the neighborhood and in the mood for soup, sure, why not. But it didn't invoke the type of cravings that cause me to make a beeline for the nearest parking spot either.
author: Sean B.

description: Great portion of conjee & portions of meat in the conjee. A good neighborhood hole in a wall go to place for conjee & dumpling noodle soups.
author: Katherine V.

description:
There are so many good things to eat at this place, especially if you are looking for chinese food that you never find at more "Americanized" places. 

My favorites are: the fish wrapped in noodle, the chinese broccoli (it's perfect: still crunchy but not bitter), the bbq pork ramen, and the spare ribs. Everything is succulent and delicious, and it's all so cheap! 

Two things I have had are a little meh: the tea quality vaires greatly, I have been there twice, once with horrible, bitter, over-steaped tea, and the second time with perfect, light tea. We also ordered the "Tofu chili lettuce" which turned out to be soft lettuce with something that looked like thousand island dressing on it, no tofu in sight. It was very salty, but after added chili sauce was ok. 

Anyway, delicious and cheap, and you should try it!
author: Leslie I.

description:
I've been here years ago, but am not certain it's the same owners. It was so-so then & hubby recently looked at the menu & noticed ramen & wanted to try it. Let's put it this way, don't expect "ramen" like you would at Santa Ramen's in San Mateo. This is ramen noodle but cooked Chinese-style. His brisket as stated by a Yelper, was mostly tendon, not so much meat. He liked it, nevertheless, $6.50. 
We tried the fried chicken wing, which was lightly dredged in flour and crispy, very good and I'd order it again, $5. 

I was disappointed by my abalone/chicken congee, $6.50. It arrived hotter than the seat heater in hubby's car and took awhile for me to eat. The porridge was watery & bland. Big chunks of chicken, slivers of ginger and 5 slices of abalone were mixed into the congee. I tried one of their Chinese donuts, which was skinny, crunchy and hard on the outside and bland. Hubby thought it was too oily. 

In the middle of the nite, I was awoken with stomach cramps, something which rarely happens to me after dining in restaurants. Hubby even said it was probably the congee. 

The place is small and at senior dining hours, 5:30PM, there were many tables filled and everyone cleared out quickly, leaving only a couple when we were leaving. The most popular dishes ordered seem to be the rice dishes in metal pots, won ton noodle, turnip cake, dumplings. The tea came in a mug and tasted like those cheap tea bags you'd find at a Howard Johnson's. Service was OK, just one woman taking care of the whole room, typical at small, indiscreet, local restaurants. Whether I return for another visit remains to be seen.
author: Ry T.

description: Pretty good porridge.  Everything is fairly fresh too because they always have a crowd.
author: hannah t.

description: This place is good for some breakfast takeout, lacking the last star because it takes them a while to get the food ready..
author: John M.

description:
Not bad. Not bad at all.

This place is tiny but food is pretty good. I know they're known for the wonton but I ordered the fishcake/seafood noodle soup and it was delish.

This is a good place to go on a cold day when you're craving porridge or something soupy to warm you up.
author: Jenny M.

description:
I HEART THIS PLACE!!! Another one of my favorite Chinese Soul Food places.

I always get the Spam and Fried Egg Macaroni Soup and the perfectly pan-fried turnip cakes. SO GOOOD! The soup is perfect for a cold foggy Sunday morning after you drank too much the night before.  Usually these two dishes fill me up nice and good but since everything is so cheap I also get the deep-fried dumplings chalk full with shrimp, those black string mushrooms, and veggies. *!!!!!!!!!* Usually they are paired with a mayo dipping sauce but that last time I went they gave the sweet and sour sauce. Boo!  And you can't forget the lemon honey hot tea. So yummy. :)
author: Rose J.

description:
This place is tiny and a quintessential-mom n pop-(without the pops?) -hole in the wall-restaurant! That sure is a mouthful and with that said, let's get on to the goods! Speaking of mouthful, you'll be sure to get stuffed with the portions they serve here. The sweet waitress lady happily seated me and took my order even though she was on her lunch break:) I heard about people finding 4 whole shrimps in their wontons and I definitely wanted to know if that was just a lucky find or if this place really is just that generous. I ordered the wonton noodle soup with ho fun. The place was actually fully seated and service took longer than expected. 

My order took a while to come out but they only had one guy in the kitchen making the food while another lady was making all the rice rolls (i'll definitely cut them some slack and you should too!) When my food finally came out, I was excited to dig in! I noticed that the rice noodles were thinner than the ones I'm used to, so I can't even really say if its homemade or the dry kind that you get at the store:( minus one star for ME not knowing the difference! I would hope its homemade since they make their own rice rolls and the consistency is the same! 

I dug into the soup and that's what either breaks it or makes it for me. Sure enough, its delicious! Light, tasty, flavorful and perfectly compliments the noodles and wontons. I continued on to test the fact or myth wonton and thank goodness I found 4 shrimps in my wonton! HURRAY for Ming Tai, because you're a WINNER in my book just doing that alone. 

I'll be sure to come back, no wait, this is my TOP choice in the area and it just so happens I frequent this area a lot. Thank you yelpers for helping me find this little hidden gem. 

By the way, they make ja leung here! (chinese donut wrapped in rice rollss!)
author: Connie C.

description:
Still a solid four! 

I love the turnip cake, its seriously as good as my mother's. This place also serves chinese donuts! I also usually don't like congee but we got the duck egg/pork one and it was REALLY good. Dip the donuts in it, tastes awesome. 

The shrimp wontons were good as usual. I don't think I'll ever get the wonton noodle soup because the noodles look awful. Wonton noodle soup should have soft squishy wide noodles (similar in texture to the wonton skin), not weird wiry yellow noodles that look like anorexic ramen. 

It seems like they might have cheap delicious Asian breakfast combos, but I couldn't read what was on the menu.
author: Emily H.

description: I got a bowl of BBQ pork/won ton soup...came with 4 medium sized won ton, and a good amount of BBQ pork...I thought this place was all about the won tons,  4 of them???? $7.45 plus tax, $8.11. I was still hungry when I left...I could get a bowl if won tons/BBQ pork, larger portions for $5 at  many places...not worth it. I gave it 2 stars cause the won ton were tasty.
author: Gene K.

description:
Breakfast combo for $3.95 from 8-11am. Includes assortment of congee, noodles, and sandwiches.

Teeny, weeny with just a few tables, this is my new favorite, local, Asian breakfast place. The wantons are loaded with shrimp and HUGE. The broth is delicious. The service is friendly. The congee is great as well.
author: Sue Y.

description:
Small clean noodle place that probably can fit no more than 25 people. Its a good place for lunch as they also serve a bunch of noodle soups. they also have a lunch special where if you buy 2 noodle or rice entrees, you get a free vegetable side dish or another rice dish. Available from 11am - 3pm. The noodles themselves are about average. Dont get the ramen as its not very good. The egg noodles are good until they soak up the msg ladened soup. Dishes range from $5-7 a pop so pretty cheap.

Bottom line: good place for lunch if graving noodle soup. CASH ONLY though.
author: Robert Y.

description:
I used to like this place. I don't think they served jook (rice soup or congee) like they used to. Other special items took a turn for...the cheap side like their Zah Leong (rice crepe wrapped chinese donut). Usually I like my chinese donut with a crispy outer shell with a crispy light and airy core. This makes the rice crepe the perfect match giving the Zah Leong a crispy inside and soft outside. What they had served was too doughy inside and when it's doughy, it's not expanded and thus not airy. The jook was good, but I felt like there wasn't a whole lot of content in it and I would like to have more than 2 slices of chinese donut on top. 

I hope the noodles are still good...
author: Jeremy L.

description:
I was around the UCSF area recently and called up my parents before my flight  back to SoCal.  What do Asian parents do when they only have a couple hours with their kids?  EAT!

 I won't be hungry, but I will always eat(and enjoy) if there is food in front of me.

My parents called up their friend who knew the area to get a recommendation for good won-ton noodles and this was the place he suggested.

We ordered: 
.won ton noodles
.won ton only with soup
.Zah Leong(sp?) - thin white doughy layer wrapped around fried long chinese 'donut'
.salted pork w/preserved egg porridge.  

I found their won ton soup well balanced. Just the right amount of delicateness and satiating mouth-feel.  My mom was amused by the size of their 'huge' won tons(just smaller than a ping pong ball).  One bite and I can visibly pick out four individual shrimps nestled in a cushion of meat enveloped by thin won ton skin. 

I recommend their won ton noodles/soup.  The porridge was good.  The Zah Long was palatable.  Not miserable, nor extraordinary.
author: C. S.

description:
This is based purely on the food only. If you can overlook the service and cleanliness, this is a great little place for a quick bite at a reasonable price. 

I came here with a buddy of mine and we always like to compare wontons or Chinese food to that of Vancouver.  Vancouver, next to Hong Kong, has the best Chinese food out there today.  Using that as our guideline, we start to rate Ming Tai Wun Tun Noodle.

The wonton noodle soup is great. It's not the best I have ever had but it's pretty damn close to being one of the better wonton houses in the city. I personally believe if they had a higher turnover ratio in their dining room then I believe their wontons would be a little fresher making it honestly a 5 star wonton house. The shrimps in the wontons aren't bad but they aren't exactly the freshest either. The soup base was good, the noodles had that crunch that you would like in a wonton noodle soup. A great combination. 

As for the rice roll, it's probably below average. It's definitely home made and the ginger on the beef rice roll was just a little overwhelming, they weren't julienned properly.  It was almost the size of a toothpick

2 beef stew wonton noodle soup 
chinese broccoli (free, part of their promotion) 
beef rice roll 

18.50
author: jason g.

description:
refer to Candice L's review. 
it captures the essence of the dining experience you will get here. the only thing i want to add is that is opens early for breakfast too.

the BEST wonton in this part of town.
close second is Win's on Taraval
C-town = Hon's on Kearny
author: Jeff W.

description:
Almost had lunch here today.

We were seated and as menu's were dropped off at the table, the server mentions to us that they are out of Ox Tail and Jook (Rice porridge).  Not a problem, I don't eat Ox Tail and I wasn't looking to have Jook for lunch any way.  Dad was here for noodles. 

( FYI, there wasn't a Hello greeting, the first words out of the lady's mouth were "No this, no that" for our greeting...I felt so welcomed! )

After a quick run down of the menu with reasonable prices, for noodles and rice plates, I decided on something down-home and hearty:  Minced Beef with Raw Egg over Rice.  

As I gave the server my order,  she tells me they are out of RICE!  What?!? Out of rice??

Lady, you should have told me you were out of rice in the first place instead of telling me you were out of Jook, I would've completely understood, no rice, means no Jook.  

Again I ask, how can you be out of rice?  Granted, you specialize in won ton, but still.... how can you be a Chinese restaurant and be out of rice?  Is it that much of a hot commodity?  You might as well close the door!

Needless to say, we left.
author: Cass J.

description: I always thought the shrimp wontons here were the best; they still are but after I ate here today with my boyfriend we both did not feel well. I think it's the MSG? Or it could be the noodles. My stomach is still cramping from the food that I had. I had the shrimp wonton with dry tossed noodle and my boyfriend had the shrimp wonton noodle soup. This place will always lack good customer service (they are lazy and inattentive), they look like they don't even want to work. Although the shrimp wontons are delicious, I wonder what goes in them. I am not coming back to the place with the delicious shrimp wontons and below average customer service.
author: Carmen L.

description:
My mom's friend took me here and it was great!!
We all ordered the Shrimp Wonton & Dumpling Soup.
it was only $6.25.. 
The soup was subtle but the dumplings were full of flavor and shrimps
plus the noodles were wonderful... slightly chewy
In fact the wonton soup so delish that.. what would you say...
I felt like I was in China??
author: Jane J.

description:
1. From open to 11am, $3 something special for fish or preserved egg congee + small side dish. Not sure if weekdays only. Super cheap breakfast/brunch.

2. Congee is watery but comes in huge bowl enough for two. Unless you're one of those big eaters. 

3. Service is a one woman show. Slow service. Be assertive. 

4. Food is good.

5. Small place. May be a 10 minute wait. Come before 10:30am if you want the aforementioned daily special. 

6. The other dishes look good too. Not $3 cheap but quite reasonable at $6-7

Conclusion: Good super cheap food, with slow service.
author: David N.

description: A bit background to the review: I am Cantonese born and raised in Canton. So my taste preference is typical Chinese. My  Chinese friends think i am a foodie and good cook. This place has the best steamed rice noodles, or Cheung Fun, in the United States as far as I know. The braised beef tripe is decent. Customers here is 99% Chinese. So come here if you want to try the real Cheung Fun. But congee, noodle soups, and other dishes are more 3-4 stars. But ultimately, we come here for what? Long live Cheung Fun!
author: Feng Z.

description:
I've dined here several times.  The won ton and dumplings are about average. They do make them large compared to other places.  Broth and noodles are similar to other won ton restaurants.  (Although the ramen isn't like any I've had anywhere else.  Nice for a change of pace) No surprise there.  During the week at certain hours, they do offer a nice extra with a minimum order of two noodle or rice dishes: a choice of greens, Chinese beef stew, or rice noodle crepe roll.  It's a small place, so don't go with more than four persons.  

Funny side note:  They always have a HK game show on TV, which my wife and I find hilarious, even though we barely understand Cantonese!
author: Stephen F.

description:
Very nice and hospitable family restaurant.

This place has really good porridge, one of the best in San Francisco.  Some other notable dishes are their deep fried dumplings and Chinese donuts.  Everything here taste extremely home made especially their porridge.  I think the dumplings can be a bit greasy at times but make sure you eat it slowly, otherwise you'll burn your tongue.  The food here cost a buck and a nickle so its always helpful on the wallet.
author: J Y.

description:
Haven't ate here for a long time, so I thought to give it another try...MAN! It was HORRIBLE!!!
FOOD was TERRIBLE; SERVICE was TERRIBLE!  1 star was already too many!
I went there (table of 3) on a weekday for lunch, the place was less than half filled, STILL, they missed my order of pork liver porridge.  The porridge finally came after my other guest finished their food.  The waitress did not apologize or even say anything about the delay.  The porridge was even worse, it was so watery that pretty much the rice and water was separated.  It was also tasteless, no flavor at all, they didn't even bother to put some chicken broth in it to enhance the flavor.  That was a complete waste of $5.50.  This place was supposed to be known for their porridge and noodle?!?!   Tak Kee Lee a few doors down & ABC across the street are WAY better!
author: Jen C.

description:
When it comes to making an attempt to satisfy my "tastes of Hong Kong" cravings this place will makes for a temporary fix. The won tons are huge with 4 shrimp inside. The noodles are a bit on the soggy side as they don't yield a crunch to them that good won ton noodles give. Their "sui kau" dumplings are good too with lots of wood ear mushroom filling and pork as well as shrimp. 

Milk tea is decent but you really have to suck if you can't make milk tea pass. 

Their porridge isn't bad also due to the fact that it actually has a consistency like porridge is supposed to have, which isn't too watery but not too thickened. 

One thing I really do enjoy here is their steamed pot rice. You can have a choice of what you want on it. My gf usually gets the mushroom and chicken while I stick to the classic preserved meats one. It's a bit of a wait for it, but always satisfying after.
author: Derrick L.

description: Their wonton is really one of the best around. All their other foods are just run of the mill Chinese soul food. Their service is not very great and it seems like that they are doing you a favor serving you. Go for the food, just don't expect any service. They have very odd hours and sometimes they are not even open when they should be.
author: Tony L.

description:
Ambiance. Hole in the wall. Waitress with an expressionless face. Think Chinese zombie. She looked so tired as if she woke up at 6a.m. from the rice paddy field. Come here for a taste of Hong Kong breakfast and atmosphere.

Food. For lunch, the won ton noodle soup (~$6) features a few meatball sized won ton and noodles in a broth. For breakfast, I tasted four dishes. Lacking salt and seasoning, the seafood porridge were showered with a few rounds of Chinese fried donuts. With a better savory touch, the preserved egg porridge was a better choice. The rice noodle with dry shrimp was nominal. The fried doughnut wrapped in rice noodle stole the show. Contrasting soft rice noodle, the crispy fried donut. A quick slather of the hoi sin sauce added needed sweet flavor.
author: Rayfil W.

description:
I went here years ago and loved the congee.  It wasn't as good as Hing Lung's but it was my second favorite in SF.  The place was constantly crowded too.  And you could order a side of preserved egg for any congee (yum).  I returned again recently and something happened over the years though; Ming Tai isn't what it used to be.  

So I ordered my usual, the pork and preserved egg congee ($4.75).  The pork pieces were too large & bland.  I don't think big pieces of meat belong in congee.  I don't want to chew anything while eating Cantonese style porridge.  The egg quality wasn't up to par.  However, the consistency and flavor of the congee were very good and I liked the slivers of fresh ginger very much.  Also, you can get the fried Chinese donut and even the kind that is wrapped up in a rice roll.  I had the latter and it was good but the donut was served COLD (not good).  

Maybe their dumplings are still good, I don't know.  I've never had them.  I'm a congee/porridge girl.  This place also has a Chinese diner feel but not the family run charm of Won Ton House.  Cash only.
author: Lolia S.

description: I absolutely fell in love with this hole in the wall. Reminded me of Hong Kong especially with the bad service and cheap tasty noodles part. The best thing is the won tun noodle soup and the up to date cantonese game show playing in the background. I will be back for more wun ton noodles!
author: Kelly C.

description:
The congee here used to have the perfect consistency.  It appears that they tinkered with the recipe sometime within the past year, and it's now slightly more watery than it should be.  Perhaps they're trying to stretch each grain of rice?

Service here has always been the pits. Rayfil W.'s description of the "waitress with an expressionless face...Chinese zombie" is perfect! If it's so tough for them to refill tea, why not just set up a small station where customers can help themselves?
author: Eating Sleeping T.

description:
The best dumpling and wonton!  They use large shrimp and flavor them well. 

The broth is a bit bland but as a little soy and it's good to go.

Also like there rice rolls with shrimp.

There is usually a short wait on Saturdays and Sundays around noon time. Me no like lines!
author: Bob S.

description: "Meh. I've experienced better" is the perfect way to sum this place up. The broth was okay I guess... but the beef was weird, and I was never sure which part of the cow was in my bowl. The same goes for the chicken soup that my friend ordered. I don't think I would bother returning here. The only reason this place is getting 2 stars and not 1 is because it's so cheap, so it wasn't an expensive mistake.
author: Beatriz A.

description:
they might as well post up a sign in front that reads. "We dont serve your kind"

my entourage of 5 and i were basically the only ones in the restaurant on a saturday brunch. 

so it took the waitress about 30 minutes just to give us menus, than another 30 minutes to place the order, than an hour to get our food, than another 30 minutes to get the bill, than another 30 minutes for her to collect the bill. no exaggerating. we asked for assistance a couple handful of times but was rudely ignored. and for what reason? no one knows.

might be the worst service ive ever had. she didnt even want to collect the tab. 

Basically, we were Unwanted here and step into the wrong restaurant.
First and Last visit. 

oh and the wontons/ dumplings were pretty good. but the service out weighed it all.

ONE STAR.
author: Rudy R.

description: Pretty good wontons and Shui gow. I would advise anyone with allergy to MSG to not eat here since I had to drink 3 glasses of water as soon as I got home, due to the effects of MSG.  The service here is apathetic.  1 star for the lousy service.  I basically had to walk over to the waitress twice to get the check.  15 mins after I asked for the check I had to walk over again and stand over her to make sure she gives me the check.  The table next to me saw this and asked for the check and takeaway box as soon as they brought the food.  :-) Nice to know my misery has benefited someone.
author: Jim J.

description: A local gem I like for their won ton noodle soup, tza leung, a dish of Chinese doughnut wrapped in rice noodles, and most of all for some of the best jook in the city!
author: Loraine T.

description:
This is the best wonton noodle I have ever had. It's very out of the way for me, but well worth it since we just drove to Fort Funston after we finished.

I had the wonton noodle soup and my bf had the beef brisket dumpling noodle soup. The portion sizes are more than fair and it definitely won't leave you hungry. The wontons are basically 4 little shrimps wrapped in a thin, soft, delicious wrap. The broth wasn't too msg tasting and the chili sauce was some of the best I have ever tasted.

It just hit the spot on a cold winter day in San Francisco. Also, the $13.50 doesn't hurt your budget in this lousy economy.
author: Angela L.

description:
Not what it's all hype to be. It's an ok Wonton house with over-sized wontons. So it has bigger wontons, but doesnt make it special. Almost $8 for the beef brisket wonton noodle soup and only comes with 3 wontons. 

The wontons is just big, that's it. Nothing special at all. A lot of MSG and no taste to the broth. Not worth it in my opinion. Go up the block to Menkee or Wonton House on the same street, Noriega street.
author: U L.

description: Great won tons! Everything on the menu is super affordable! Rice plates, noodles/won ton dishes for $6.00 and appetizers for anywhere b/t $3-$4. Super delicious. You would never think this dingy little shop squeezed b/t a sushi restaurant and a bar was worth while. Don't judge a book by it's cover?
author: Lily W.

description: This place is a bit small, but I love the won ton noodles here, and the beef brisket! It's delicious! And sometimes they even give you a free rice noodle dish for some reason. I don't ask why, but hey its free why not. My new favorite wonton noodle spot.
author: Terry S.

description: My friend kept raving about the porridge from this place so I really wanted to try it out . We were finally able to wake up kinda early today and come here . The iced lemon tea was not bad . The abalone and chicken porridge was not bad but failed to impress me ... probably because I'm really picky . The porridge had a lot of chicken in it . The pieces of chicken were alright ... they were pretty smooth . The wonton noodle soup with beef haslet wasn't that good . The beef haslet tasted like it was overcooked . The wonton and the noodles didn't taste that good either . However , what really impressed me was their BBQ rice noodles . They were so yummy and full of flavor !!
author: Eileen L.

description: Worst fried chicken wings I've ever eaten! But other than that I guess their food is pretty decent.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
I found this place on Yelp when my boyfriend wasn't feeling well and needed good 'ol Chinese comfort food, i.e., porridge. We just wanted take-out, but were left standing for quite some time before anyone came to see what we wanted. It took a while to get the food, as the parking meter ran out. I was skeptical about the porridge, but the beef slice porridge and the duck egg with pork porridge were both delicious. There was good flavor and the rice was also of a good consistency.

I think we'll come back to try their won ton noodles or other dishes and dine in.
author: Ellen S.

description: Good homemade style wonton for a very decent price. Most dishes are around 5 bucks and come out pretty quick within a couple minutes. Great for when you need something warm or to cure a hangover. This place may not look like anything special, but the food is delicious. Always satisfied after leaving this place.
author: Patrick L.

description: Huge dumplings and won tons.  If you come for lunch during the weekday with a friend, you get a free side of greens, beef brisket stew, or rice roll. I like that they don't skimp on the shrimp.  Each won ton has at least one full-sized shrimp.  Just be sure to bring cash.
author: Marleen C.

description:
I think this place is great.  pork lard in shrimp dumplings?  if that's what makes it taste better, then so be it!!
another plus is that it's right up the street from me so add a little spicy sauce to the soup and you have the best cure for a weekend hangover.
author: Rio K.

description:
It's Friday night and that means, I don't want to cook.  And it's also raining.  And I'm hungry.  Let's go get some noodle soup!  Yay...!!

After yelping, we decided to go to Ming Tai Wun-Tun Noodle place on Noriega Ave between 31st and 32nd Ave.  The good thing about 8 o,n, ib a rainy Friday is that we found parking right away.  And the place only had 2 other customers.  Just the way we like it.  Nice and quiet dinner on a Friday evening.  After looking at the menu, we decided on Beef Brisket Noodle soup and BBQ Pork Wonton Noodle soup.

My fiance's beef noodle soup came out first -- it smelled really good and had lots of beef on it.  And not chucks of fat, just the way he likes it.  And my noodle soup came out and it had 3 BIG pieces of wonton and about 6 slicesof BBQ pork.  Each of those wonton had FOUR shrimps.  Yeap..FOUR shrimps.  I was amazed.  The soups were delish!!  We didn't taste much MSG.  I don't even think they use MSG.  But who knows.  The proportion was just perfect too -- not too small and not too big.  It was just the right amount.  And the red chili that they had at the table?  Well, it was wow!!  It's so darn good.  I think they may have added vinegar to it?  Or something.  Damn..I long for it now.  ha ha.  For both soups, we paid ~$14.  No complaints from us what-so-ever!  We'll definitely go back!

I do agree with other people -- the place is kind of small.  I think it may fit about 20-25 people.  But it's definitely clean.  And they only accept cash.  

Have fun visiting this place -- it's so good!
author: Joyce L.

description:
Fun and jook is my livelihood. Whenever I head over to Hong Kong or China, the first thing I do is run into a wonton joint and get my fill. Back here at home, I try to replicate that experience any chance I get.

Ming Tai does the job better than most places in SF, but that isn't saying much. The service staff faithfully carries the attitude of a Hong Kong jook joint. They are dismissive, rude, but generally pleasant.

Their menu has all the staples you expect: assorted jooks, dumplings, funs, and braised noodles. The jooks work; its consistency and flavor warms your soul like any jook should. Try the Sampan if you're into seafood, or the Thousand Year Old Black Egg and Lean Pork if you're, er, into that. Be adventurous, people.

The dumplings are tasty and huge, but the broth and noodles they sit in are unremarkable. And that basically sums up this place: pretty good food, but no wow factor.
author: Derek L.

description:
this place is tiny. 

i really like their lunch special; comes with a meal a side dish and a drink (hot drinks, they don't charge but cold drinks is an extra 1$) 

if you're craving for porridge or wonton noodles, this is the place to go..
author: Valerie N.

description:
A 4 star for food, 3 star for the place being too small, average 3.5 stars to be fair.

My mother in law recommended us to try this little noodle shop and said that she visits there all the time.  I and my hubby used to go to Tak Kee Lee and we decided to give Ming Tai a try when our favorite Tak Kee Lee was packed with people and there's a waiting line inside.

Ming Tai is a small noodle shop, the tables are so closely placed next to each other.  In the weekend, there's no set meal for order.  So, we ordered individual items, a Cha Siu Won Ton Ramen, a fishball flat noodle and a Cheung Fun.  

I like the flat noodle, the fishballs are just average, not really special.

My hubby likes the ramen.  The wontons are big and tasty.

Cheung Fun is fresh and the sauce is nice.

End up we paid $19 including tips.  It's not very expensive but both I and my hubby walked out with a feeling that we need some more food.  Finally, we went home and had a half portion of the sandwich that we bought yesterday evening in Safeway.  We may possibly come back when our friend Tak Kee Lee is packed and we want some good noodle soups.
author: Roserrele W.

description:
This place is ideal for barbarians.  I went to this place after reading the reviews of Ken K and Stanley L.  They both 5-starred it.  I was looking forward to trying it.

Unfortunately, I didn't like my bowl of chicken noodle soup much.  I wouldn't order it again.  The chicken was strongly and deeply flavored with something - not sure what - maybe MSG or 5-spice.  I couldn't really taste a chicken flavor.  .  The pieces of chicken, like the wontons that others in my party had, were huge.  The wontons had 2-3 shrimps in each.  I found it difficult to pick up the big chicken pieces with my chopstick.  Sheesh, can't they make their wontons and chicken pieces smaller so I don't have to chew pieces off like a barbarian?  Just take those big wontons and make them into 2 or 3 separate ones.  If they did that I would up my rating to 3 stars...but still not go back.

I would say this place is a run-of-the-mill small wonton house.  It holds maybe 25 people.
author: Sun W.

description:
There are won ton restaurants all over the city and when we stumbled upon this restaurant a couple months ago we thought it was pretty damn good, but now that my parents have also given it their stamp of approval I feel confident in spreading the word on Yelp also. What hooked us in were the size of the won ton and dumplings that are served at Ming Tai. The dumplings are extra large and packed with shrimp and black mushrooms. Very simple, but the ingredients are fresh and they don't skimp on the shrimp. For the carb conscious you can also get the won ton or dumplings without noodles and it's still a filling dish. If you are going to order the noodles I would definitely recommend ordering the egg noodles over the ramen as the egg noodles have a lot more flavor.

The jook also has the right texture and is flavorful without needing to put too much extra soy sauce or white pepper in it. Another popular dish is the Chinese donut wrapped in chun fun that they serve with a sauce of peanut butter and oyster sauce. It sounds strange, but the sauce is actually a great combination of flavors.
author: A and K W.

description:
Best wonton noodle place in San Francisco, hands down.

Trust me, I KNOW. I got the I'm-from-oversea knowledge and experience.

I know this place gets smacks for the poor customer service. To me, its just authentic. If you've been to multiple no-frills, hole in the wall joints in Hong Kong, you'll know what I mean. It stems from a no-tips required tradition found in most Asia and European countries.

Easy solution to avoid the "authenthicity"... get take outs.
author: Stanley L.

description:
there was a constant line today at lunch, and good job we got there as a bunch of tables were leaving...... wow this place was busy... Ok so the service was a not too great, but we were here for a quick, cheap and simple lunch and we got what we wanted.

Quick look at the menu and there were various combinations of noodles, shrimp dumpling, wontons.... from previous experience a 'SHRIMP' dumpling or Shrimp Wonton is never just shrimp- like my parents they try and sneak fatty meat in every thing, saying it makes things more 'flavourful' so I played safe and ordered the black mushroom noodle soup- REALLY GOOD- who wouldve thought to use whole shitake mushrooms as dumpling substitutes?! 

The man ordered the wonton and bbq pork noodle soup and was impressed with the wontons..  must say beware of the MSG, my mouth was tingly and was thirsty for hours after..

the rice rolls are pretty good too, get to them while they are steaming hot...... crowd was mixed- families with their kids, the odd grandpa with them, young teenagers taking advantage of the big bowls of jook. one appetizer and and two bowls of noodles soup will set you back around 20 dollars....
author: Sushi Y.

description: Go for their carrot cake and fish porridge. Only $5.50 per bowl, where else can you get such good value congee?
author: Chloe L.

description: Ming Tai Wun Tun Noodle has the best won ton noodle of all time!! it is cheap and gooooood!! :] Boyfriend got the duck over rice, it was greasy but it was good and tasty!!! I would come here again anytime! :]
author: Melissa G.

description:
This restaurant is a hole in the wall which was what ultimately enticed me to patronize it.  My honey was apprehensive.  I convinced him that there was some fantastic goodness overshadowed by the simple appearance of the place.

He had the beef brisket + dumpling noodle, and I had the preserved duck + lean pork porridge.  Huge portions, but great for us cuz' it was good!  Great flavors.  And the food came out fast.  The ladies that work there are a bit slow and aloof, but that doesn't bug me.
author: Jeanne L.

description: One of the better places in San Francisco for won ton noodle.  They give you four big pieces per order.  Their congee is good too.  Too bad they usually don't open in the evenings except maybe for Fridays and Saturdays.
author: H K.

description: My  5 year old son took me here for my bday lunch.  And this place is really a 3.5 star.  I had the beef stew wonton soup here and the broth was good.  The wonton was good but would have been better if it was more bite-size and a few more wontons in the noodle soup.  Also if it was real actual wonton noodles...it would have been totally awesome.  Still no place beats Hon's on Kearny.
author: Allison T.

description: I've always craved congee when I'm sick or its cold out and Ming Tai has always come through with flavor and bang for your buck. I'm a big fan of their sliced fish with lettuce congee and the chinese donut roll with peanut/soy sauce. If you are ordering take out, be warned, they pick up the phone and respond in chinese so don't be deterred by the language barrier and order to your stomachs delight!
author: Rich L.

description: This place has good congee for the cheap price. The chinese donut is smaller here and over fried (too crispy and hard, so wont get soggy unless you let it sit in your congee for a long time). The restaurant is also really small. But I'll still eat here since its not in chinatown and so parking is easier.
author: Jess H.

description: Nice cheap spot for good congee.  But my favorite thing on the menu is Ja leurng (Chinese donut roll) which is a deep fried dough wrapped in a white thin layer of noodle. Comes with a couple dipping sauces.
author: Brian T.

description:
Best wonton place ever!!!  The wontons are HUGE and it taste really really good.  I thought Wonton House was a good place until I came to Ming Tai.  Now I can't go back to Wonton House.  

If you're not into wontons, they also have great porridge there.  I usually order the preserved egg w/ pork and could never finish the whole bowl.  The consistency is just right.  Not too thick or too thin.

Cons - limited in seating and depending on the day, the waitresses are not always very friendly.
author: Esther L.

description:
OMG YES! HUGE WONTONS! 

I've been here twice for the wonton noodles and can definitely say they satisfied my cravings. The regular wonton or dumpling and noodle orders come with 4 giants sized wontons or dumplings! (The difference between wontons and dumplings? Wontons are spherical, filled with pork and whole shrimp. Dumplings are more of an oblong shape, with the addition of a few strips of wood ear fungus to the pork and shrimp filling). I don't know that ordering the beef stew version is worth it since I haven't tried it yet, I would think it might be better to just order a plate of that separately.

Tip: If you come on weekdays around lunch time bring a buddy! There's a special where if you order two noodle soups, you can get a free item: some cooked chinese broccoli, a small order of chinese beef stew, or some cheurng fun. 

The only complaint I had was that when I ordered the chinese fritter with the rice noodle wrapped around it, it wasn't very hot when I got it. :(

Other than that, I don't know what other people complain so much about. Sure it's expensive if you're comparing it to eating wontons you had in China. But it's not that expensive. A good bowl of japanese ramen would cost about the same (unless you're one of those cheapskates who thinks ramen only comes in "instant" packages at the market). And what's so bad about big wontons? If I take a bite of a wonton and see a huge shrimp inside, that's good! And the service is apathetic sometimes sure, but this is a genuine chinese place. This ain't no wonton place run by Charles Phan (no offense to him, i'm sure his food is amazing)!
author: Crystal L.

description:
egantic bowls of soup/jook/whatever you're eating.  since they've recently remodeled, it's much cleaner than before, though still very much reminds me of being in china.

the won ton is huge.  like chernobyl won tons.  and the food comes out super quick.  i thought the beef stew (ngao lam) was pretty good.
author: Jason J.

description: SORRY, I never had the food here because when my friend brought me here the othey day WORST THING HAPPEN. After we ordered, while waiting for our food I saw something looking at me. When I looked, it was a rat staring at me! I told the lady I wanted to have my food to-go, paid, left and threw the food away! I couldn't eat it ....
author: Frankie L.

description:
I have a new crush! The shrimp dumpling noodles at Ming Tai are mutant wontons that are the size of a 10 year old's fist. They are full of plump, whole sweet shrimp (not the gelatinous force-meat product that sometimes fills shrimp dim sum and dumpling products), crunchy strips of wood ear mushrooms, and chivey bits. Giant they are. The swirling bed of yellow egg noodles are perfect, it's not difficult to make good yellow noodles and these are as they should be, cooked to the proper Asian version of al dente. Sparkling, long simmered broth, the appropriate balance of saltiness, a few leaves of cooked lettuce, and more chivey bits complete the bowl.
Also tried the beef brisket wonton noodle soup. Rich, dark beef broth, copious chunks of tender brisket and lots of chewy fatty bits, plus wontons the size of golf balls encasing the same sweet, whole shrimp, and yummy yellow noodles.
Clientele is 98% Asian, and the place is small, about six 2-tops and three 4-tops. Line at the door, and simple menu of congee, dry noodles and noodle soup, and a few side dishes. Feel free to take the pale palates along, as they also serve a handful of classic sandwiches (ham and cheese, etc), different macaroni dishes (no idea what those are like), and fries. Noodles are cheap (about $4-6) and filling enough. The best I've found in SF so far. 
Sigh, I love new crushes!
author: Candice L.

description:
I haven't eat at this part of town yet.  So I was wondering and look at all the windows.  First I went to ABC, actually sat down but we look around and see what other people were eatting and glance at the menu, we make a run for the door like pants on fire.
Finally we went across the st.  and order a quick  wonton noodle soup and rice and brisket.  The wonton was nice big bowl and giant wontons each problemly have 4 little shrimps in it!  The broth is just so so.  I think the soup at Wonton King was better but the portion at W.K. was small, tiny, I was still hungry when I walk out.  The noodle was better then the broth, al dente just the way I like it.  The brisket was another story.  Tough and goowy, meat that don't taste like beef,(mystery meat?)
They serve it with rice on the side.  1 serving is enough to serve 2 people and a midget.  If it didn't taste so disppointing, I would doggy bag it home.:-(
I shouldn't complain because the price is right.  Maybe next time, I would go for the wonton again and then some other dish that is suggested here.  This place is cheap, how do they make any money?This is a hole in a wall but cleaner then most hole in the wall.
author: Mar H.

description: I just discovered this place today. I tried the won ton/shrimp dumpling soup which comes with 3 shrimp dumplings and 3 won tons and it was delicious. I also had a plate of fried shrimp dumplings as an appetizer to share but it was a bit too greasy. I peeled off some of the skin and then it was pretty good. Overall, this place is a bit pricey for what you get but it was delicious. I will be back!
author: Diane M.

description: I have heard about this place for so long. Everyone always says that you have to have the wont on here. Finally my mom, the bf and I came here for Saturday brunch. I had the won ton fun and it was really good. The broth was clear , not greasy and just had a really pure flavor. When I say pure, I mean that it didn't taste like there was a ton of msg in the broth.  The won ton is actually pretty good sized and there were quite a few in the bowl. The only reason that I didn't give this place 5 stars is because the service is okay. i wouldn't say that I come here for the service.
author: carebear l.

description:
my entire 3.5 stars goes to the food and the food only. 

the place is like the size of a small hallway and they squish as many tables as they can in there. you feel uncomfortably close to the person next to you/behind you and it takes forever to get a glass of water, tea, utensils, check... basically, you should be prepared to bus your own table when youre there. 

that being said - food is very good! its authentic and delicious - reminds me of places in hong kong. things i liked: (prepare yourself for the awful descriptions here since my chinese sucks)

-rice clay pot with tiny spareribs
-chinese fried doughnut covered in a thin fat noodle with sweet soy sauce and peanut dipping sauce
-won ton noodles
-preserved egg with pork porridge
author: Jessica C.

description: The dumplings are the largest I have been served and the quality is always very good.  The soup is definitely not oily and healthier than most places.  There is also jook which is very good.
author: Ginny M.

description: SIze matters...and with won tons too! I don't know exactly how many pieces of shrimp came together to form each of the balls but it has be between 4 to 6. It's like Voltron but with won tons. It's a bit shocking at first to see how big they are but you quickly get over it since it is very tasty! It's hard to get the noodle, soup, and won ton right but these guys have it down.
author: Barney M.

description:
I'm usually pretty iffy about shrimp but this is my favorite place to have won-ton noodle soup. The won-tons have at least 2 whole shrimp in them each and I am crazy about the texture of their egg noodles. 

Service can be spartan at times, but I am here for my soup, and sometimes a hot mug of almond milk.

This place is crazy busy on week-ends.
author: Sophie M.

description: This is one of my regular breakfast places every weekend and I have to say every time I go there I'm pretty satisfied. Around brunch-lunch it's still pretty crowded. The store is small and a bit cramped but once you get seated that's when the real experience starts. All their shrimp rolls are REALLY good. The wontons are really big and tasty. I'm a big fan of their congee as well. This just goes to show that good things do come in small packages.
author: Julie L.

description: Typically shabby dive-y Chinese restaurant surroundings with grouchy service (so if you prize ambiance, this place is not for you), but if you prize the best dumplings in San Francisco, then you should come here and order the dumplings.   I ate them and then spent the next forty five minutes randomly hugging my husband (who picked the joint as our lunch destination) on account of transitive food happiness.
author: Jan C.

description: Yummy won ton!  They are HUGE.  I only got 4 of them with my noodles (I got them with ramen instead of the regular noodles - just for a change), but they were so big, it didn't matter.  Very flavorful.  We wrote our name on the clipboard at the front and had to wait about 10 minutes for a table.  Service was a bit slow.  The waitress didn't smile at all and wouldn't even look at us while we were ordering.  She was looking out the window the whole time.  We also had to wait about 15-20 minutes for our food.  Maybe the cook was making everything at once because about 4 tables got their food at the same time.  The won ton is sooo good though.  Definitely worth a trip back!
author: Kris L.

description:
won tons are ginormous (5 in a bowl without noodles) and flavorful and packed with shrimp, as others have mentioned
for the area though, $1 per wonton is a little pricey
fish congee was a little more watery compared to won ton house in my opinion
chinese broccoli soft
author: Rob C.

description: Huge won tons, huge price tag!  Thank you for not skimping on the shrimp, but please ease off on the bill.  Does it have abalone in the won tons?  Don't get me wrong, the food is good.  Knock off $1 per bowl and you get yourself another star.
author: Ezduzit S.

description: Yes, the Wontons are bigger but hey the pricetag is bigger too.  For the money, I go to Lam Hoa Thuan on Irving.  Same price will get you way more ingredients.  But you have to try to know, right?  Parking might be a bit easier here but make that 3 to 5 min drive over to Irving.  You'll thank yourself once you've started digging in.
author: Mark W.

description: I love the congee at Ming-Tai! Hing Lung is still #1, but I live in the Sunset, so Ming-Tai is much more convenient. The congee is smooth, tasty and always piping hot. It's the best for cold rainy days. (However, the congee is only the freshest in the mornings. Don't get it if you go there in the evening.) You get a big bowl for like $4. On the weekdays, there's a special where you can get a bowl of congee and a side - all for just $3.50! Can't beat that! Service is ok, but what can you expect from a tiny casual Chinese restaurant in the Sunset?
author: Cee J.

description:
the shrimp dumplings are really good.  i usually get them with lo mein.  they have a lot of side dishes that are good - shrimp cheurng fun and ja lerng.  i'm surprised that they're not open for dinner or on wednesdays since chinese places are open all the time.

update - they're now open until 9pm fri-sun.
author: julia t.

description: This is a good noodle place.  Great shrimp dumplings!  The dumplings are big and very tasty.  This is a small place.  There may be a wait during peak times.  Lots of people come here for take out.
author: Stacey L.

description: Came here like .. once.. a couple years ago. Don't really remember how the food was like, but I believe that it was fine. The workers there are real kind.
author: Katherine C.

description: This is my favorite chinese noodle place in the city!  Its wonton and shrimp dumplings are simply the best-in-class!  They are not only big in size, but also juicy and fresh!  I also love its iced milk tea, shrimp cheung fun and beef stew.  If you're looking for a place with the best HK-style wonton noodle, this is it!  Of course, this is not a place to please your gf in your first date either  :p
author: Jacky L.

description: I've eaten here four times in the last two weeks, so I obviously think that it's pretty good.  Ginormous wontons in the wonton soup.  The rest of the stuff is very mediocre.  E.g., I would pass on the barbecued pork (either homemade -- not in a good way, or purchased from a not-so-good place) and the fried donut wrapped in fun (kind of small).
author: Rich H.

description: best won ton in sf!!! i challenge yo to find a better won. keep up the good food jenny!!!
author: dion l.

description: I absolutely love their huge won tons. The congee is good too. Prices wre good. It's really smal, so you might have to wait in line.
author: bob k.

description: A solid noodle joint that stuffs a whole family of shrimp into each wonton, along with plenty of tasty sides to comfort your soul.  It's pretty far out of the way, but worth the drive.  Love finishing off a bowl of this good stuff and then walking a few blocks down to Polly Ann Ice Cream for dessert.
author: Patricia L.

description: my friends chose this place.. it is small but has some great business... their won tons are big and  delicious and their beef rice noodle and fish congee are great too... i saw other people ordering spareribs with rice.. looks heLLa gOod~~what a lunch feast for me and my friends.... their prices range from 5 to 7 dollars...
author: Lily T.

description: Other than the rice porridge and won-ton, worth to try their rice plate (in the little steel pot), tasty!
author: E C.

description: Typical chinese noodle shop. I had the wonton and dumpling noodles for $7.50. They were the largest wontons and dumplings I've ever had and they were good with alot of shrimp. But if I had known that they use lard then I wouldn't eat that again. Is it true? I dont know.
author: VVVV H.

description: The first time i went here was like 5 years ago i was told the wontons and dumplings with noodles is off the hook .... so i order it when it came out i was like damn those wontons and dumplingss are huge!!   biggest dumps i eva seen !! lol didnt sound right anywayz freakin good!!  the appetizer like the noodle wrap doughnuts are good also the beef and shrimp noodle wrap are good appetizers .... man i want some haven't been here for a while!!
author: geo t.
